item.title: Paris attacks 2015: Accused complains of conditions
item.description: Salah Abdeslam and 19 other defendants are accused of involvement in France's worst post-WWII attack.

item.title: Afghanistan: Women protest against all-male Taliban government
item.description: Dozens of women march in Kabul and in Badakhshan province, angry at the new Taliban government.

item.title: Russian emergencies minister Zinichev dies on Arctic drill
item.description: Yevgeny Zinichev was killed while trying to save a cameraman who had fallen into water, reports say.

item.title: Ethiopia's Tigray crisis: Mass graves found - Amhara officials
item.description: The bodies of some 119 civilians are found by local officials - rebel forces deny responsibility.

item.title: Robert E Lee statue: Virginia removes contentious memorial as crowds cheer
item.description: The statue became a focal point for the protests following the death of George Floyd last spring.

item.title: Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte to stand as vice-president
item.description: Rivals accuse the president, barred from a second term, of seeking to cling on to power.

item.title: Israeli troops make arrests over Palestinian prison break
item.description: Several relatives of the six inmates who escaped Gilboa prison are reportedly taken into custody.

item.title: Spanish bishop quit for love for erotic writer
item.description: Xavier Novell was a traditional and controversial bishop who resigned for "personal reasons".

item.title: West African leaders suspend Guinea from Ecowas following coup
item.description: The military junta has released prisoners detained during deposed President Alpha CondÃ©'s rule

item.title: India: One dead and many missing after boats collide in Assam
item.description: A massive rescue operation is under way in Assam to find at least 30 people still missing.

item.title: Brazil's Bolsonaro: Only God will remove me from power
item.description: With his approval rating at a low, Brazil's leader strikes a defiant note on independence day.

item.title: Denmark tells some migrants to work for benefits
item.description: The prime minister says the new rules are aimed at women from non-Western backgrounds.

item.title: Paris attacks: Historic day of reckoning for night of terror
item.description: Survivors and families attend the long-awaited trial of 20 men accused of the deadly 2015 attacks.

item.title: Afghanistan: Could Pakistani drones hit the Panjshir Valley?
item.description: There are claims that Pakistan has used drones against anti-Taliban forces in Afghanistan.

item.title: Somali feminist: Facebook is being used to silence me
item.description: Hanna Paranta has faced assassination attempts and now online attacks for helping abused women.

item.title: Britney Spears: Singer's conservatorship case explained
item.description: The ongoing arrangement has sparked a public backlash from fans who support the #FreeBritney movement.

item.title: The Taliban embrace social media: 'We too want to change perceptions'
item.description: Famed for their shunning of technology, the Taliban are realising they need to be on social media too.

item.title: Nizar Banat: The death shaking the Palestinian leadership
item.description: The killing of Nizar Banat in Palestinian custody has fuelled rare protests calling for change.

item.title: India jewellery ad starring trans model wins hearts
item.description: The ad is being praised in India where popular culture still portrays transgender people as caricatures.

item.title: The South African farm turning flies into food for pets - and maybe people
item.description: A South African company is aiming to take advantage of a new interest in protein-rich insects.

item.title: Why coders love the AI that could put them out of a job
item.description: Artificial intelligence is getting better at penning code but still a long way from working alone.

item.title: Mexico earthquake: Lights seen in sky during tremor near Acapulco
item.description: The magnitude-seven quake struck the country's Pacific coast, near the resort of Acapulco.

item.title: Taliban fire shots to disperse protest in Kabul
item.description: Hundreds of protesters took to the streets on Tuesday to demand women's rights and denounce Taliban rule.

item.title: Australian bush rescue: Mother's reunion with boy lost for four days
item.description: Three-year-old Anthony "AJ" Elfalak is recovering with family after going missing for four days.

item.title: Mexico: Flash flooding sweeps away cars after heavy rain
item.description: Heavy rain in central Mexico sparked flash floods in Ecatepec and NexahualcÃ³yotl.

item.title: Esports: Why are there so few professional women gamers?
item.description: There are no female players in the top 300 earners in esports, according to research shared with BBC News.

item.title: Chaos and confusion: The frenzied final hours of the Afghan government
item.description: Through interviews with insiders, BBC News has pieced together an account of how Afghanistanâs government unravelled.

item.title: Taliban need UN's humanitarian aid - UN boss
item.description: In return, the new regime must provide conditions for the UN to work in Afghanistan, secretary general tells BBC.

item.title: Afghanistan: The pledge binding al-Qaeda to the Taliban
item.description: The history of the complex relationship between the two groups.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban accused of killing pregnant police officer
item.description: The killing comes amid increasing reports of escalating repression of women in Afghanistan.

item.title: US Senator Lindsey Graham: 'We will be going back into Afghanistan'
item.description: Republican Senator Lindsey Graham believes there will be no choice as "the threat will be so large".
